awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Regulation of the transition from primary to secondary ovarian follicle development by androgens in a teleost model
awd_abstract_narration:
Production of a fertilizable vertebrate egg is a complex process in which a small and relatively unspecialized cell, the oocyte, is provisioned with a variety of maternal materials that support fertilization and early embryonic development. Thus, many aspects of "egg quality", the term used to describe an egg that can be successively fertilized and lead to a viable offspring, are determined relatively early. The project will use ovaries from a non-mammalian vertebrate model to determine how early oocyte growth is regulated by hormones. Because of the conserved nature of egg development in vertebrates, the research will improve fundamental knowledge of egg development in vertebrates, including humans and agriculturally important animals, and may lead to the development of improved methods to overcome reproductive dysfunction of captive-reared fish in conservation and commercial aquaculture. The project will integrate research and education by recruiting undergraduate and graduate students from California State University Fullerton, a Hispanic Serving Institution, to work with a diverse group of scientists from the University of Washington, and with researchers from a federal agency. The goal is to train the next generation of scientists how to apply molecular tools, bioinformatics, and histology to biological questions while gaining an in-depth understanding of animal physiology, endocrinology, and reproduction. The research will be presented to the scientific community and to the public via established partnerships to provide trainees with service-learning experience.

The basic physiology of female teleost reproduction, particularly during the later stages of oogenesis (e.g., vitellogenesis, maturation, ovulation) is fairly well understood. By contrast, comparatively little is known about the transition into puberty. In the ovary, this occurs when the primary growth ovarian follicles (containing developing oocytes) are recruited into secondary growth. Using a well-characterized in vitro model using coho salmon ovarian explants, the investigators have shown that 11-ketotestosterone (11KT), a teleost-specific aromatizable androgen, promotes the development of primary and early secondary ovarian follicles, associated with identification via RNA-Seq of altered mRNA levels of hundreds to thousands of genes, depending on stage. These changes are consistent with altered hormonal signaling pathways, tissue remodeling, and the progression to an early secondary ovarian follicle phenotype. The project will further explore the hypothesis that androgens are essential for early ovarian follicle by exploiting advances in proteomics, quantitative steroid biochemical analyses and the availability of homologous recombinant gonadotropins to: characterize the major endogenous androgens present in the female coho salmon during the onset of puberty; characterize androgen receptors; document the development-related changes in ovarian follicle proteins using cutting-edge proteomics; and explore the potential roles of gonadotropins in regulating previtellogenic ovarian follicle development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While much is known about the later stages of fish reproduction, the early stages remain largely unexplored. Our study aimed to identify the molecular and cellular changes necessary during primary growth of ovarian follicles and the transition into secondary growth. Using coho salmon as a model, we used advanced techniques to study proteins and hormones in the ovaries of female coho salmon during early ovarian follicle growth and development (i.e., late perinucleolar, early cortical alveolus staged ovarian follicles). This information is important because problems that occur during early ovarian development can lead to poor egg quality and fertility issues.

Our research integrated education and hands-on training for students, fostering the next generation of scientists. Students involved in this project gained valuable hands-on experience with molecular tools, bioinformatics, and proteomics, enhancing their academic and professional development. Our project involved graduate (Master’s-level) and undergraduate students from California State University Fullerton (CSUF), a Hispanic Serving Institution, and scientists from the University of Washington (UW). CSUF students spent several weeks during the summer at UW and continued work at their home campus. Additionally, our research group met monthly online to discuss experimental design, data collection and analysis, and data interpretation.

CSUF students worked with a postdoctoral researcher learning how to perform in vitro tissue cultures using salmon ovarian tissues. Short-term ovarian explant cultures were conducted using salmon gonadotropins to study their effects on ovarian development. Long-term exposure studies were also conducted with 11-ketotestosterone (11-KT) to determine its impact on ovarian follicle size and proteome. CSUF students were also mentored by a UW research scientist. CSUF students actively participated in a series of proteomics-based bioinformatics workshops let by the research scientist. Students received paraffin histology training at CSUF.

Our research team selected candidate proteomics biomarkers for targeted analysis of ovarian tissue fragments. We identified over 5700 ovarian proteins using advanced mass spectrometry providing a comprehensive dataset on stage-dependent and experimentally induced protein expression. Gene Ontogeny enrichment analysis revealed significant structural and functional changes during ovarian development, particularly during the transition from late perinucleolar (LPN) to early cortical alveolus stages (ECA). These findings enhance our understanding of how androgens and the endocrine system equip ovarian follicles with the necessary molecular and cellular machinery to respond to endocrine signals and promote follicle growth.

The involvement of students from California State University Fullerton and collaboration with the University of Washington has enriched the educational experience, provided hands-on training, and fostered the next generation of scientists. Student participation was critical in selecting and analyzing proteomics data, contributing significantly to the research outcomes. Our commitment to sharing our findings through scientific conferences, peer-reviewed publications, and public presentations ensures that the knowledge gained from this project will benefit both the scientific community and the broader public.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2024
Modified by: Kristy Forsgren
